Abstract:

Title: Death and Life of Catalysts: a Theory-Guided Unified Approach for Non-Critical Metal Catalyst Development

The proposed project, DeLiCat, seeks to revolutionize the field of catalysis by developing a new generation of non-critical metal-based catalysts through a theory-guided unified approach. Recognizing the limitations of traditional trial-and-error methods, our goal is to formulate a hierarchical computational strategy that integrates advanced chemical theory, computational screening, and experimental approaches from both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. This strategy aims to design and synthesize durable, cost-effective, highly active, and selective catalysts for the hydrogenation of carboxylic acids and their esters, as well as for acceptorless dehydrogenation of alcohols.

Our approach will employ computer simulations to uncover complex reaction networks, enabling us to direct selectivity and prevent catalyst deactivation paths. By designing novel multifunctional catalyst systems, we will facilitate efficient knowledge exchange loops that guide and validate theoretical predictions through rigorous experimental studies. The project aligns with crucial fields of application including biomass valorization, hydrogen technology, and both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis.

Expected outcomes from DeLiCat include the establishment of new theoretical concepts and methodological advances that will lead to the creation of novel superior catalyst systems. These catalysts are anticipated to enhance the efficiency of liquid phase chemical transformations, thus contributing to sustainable chemical practices.

By advancing first principles-guided catalyst design, DeLiCat represents a significant leap forward in the development of environmentally friendly and economically viable catalysts. This project holds the promise of mitigating the dependency on critical metals, thereby impacting the global challenge of resource scarcity and promoting sustainable industrial processes.

Abstract:

The "Death and Life of Catalysts: a Theory-Guided Unified Approach for Non-Critical Metal Catalyst Development" (DeLiCat) project represents an innovative leap toward revolutionizing the design and synthesis of catalysts using non-critical metals. This initiative aims to address the need for sustainable and economically viable catalysts in chemical transformations crucial to hydrogen technology and biomass valorization.

Our primary objectives are to: 1) formulate a hierarchical computational strategy for the design and synthesis of non-critical metal-based catalysts; 2) develop new, durable, and cost-effective catalysts for the hydrogenation of carboxylic acids and their esters; and 3) create catalysts for acceptorless dehydrogenation of alcohols. These goals will be accomplished by integrating advanced chemical theory with computational screening, complemented by experimental approaches from both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis fields. The project will establish an efficient knowledge exchange loop to bridge theoretical models and experimental validation.

DeLiCat's innovative approach will utilize computer simulations to uncover complex reaction networks, thereby enabling the direct control of selectivity and the prevention of catalyst deactivation paths. The design of novel multifunctional catalyst systems will be guided by first principles, aiming to establish new theoretical concepts and methodological advances that can be practically applied.

The expected outcomes of DeLiCat include the development of novel superior catalyst systems that are highly active, selective, and resilient, which are anticipated to contribute significantly to liquid phase chemical transformations. Our approach promises to catalyze methodological advances and practical applications in fields such as homogeneous catalysis, heterogeneous catalysis, hydrogen technology, and biomass valorization, thereby enhancing the sustainability and efficiency of chemical processes worldwide.

Abstract:

The "Death and Life of Catalysts: a Theory-Guided Unified Approach for Non-Critical Metal Catalyst Development" (DeLiCAT) project presents an innovative strategy to revolutionize the field of catalysis. By integrating advanced chemical theories with computational and experimental methods, DeLiCAT aims to design novel catalyst systems that are not reliant on critical metals. These catalysts will be more durable, cost-effective, and efficient for crucial reactions such as the hydrogenation of carboxylic acids and their esters, as well as acceptorless dehydrogenation of alcohols.

The objectives of DeLiCAT are to establish a hierarchical computational strategy for the design and synthesis of these new catalysts, and to develop sustainable chemical transformations that leverage non-critical metal resources. By employing a combination of chemical theory, computational screening, and experimental approaches spanning both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis, DeLiCAT will facilitate an efficient knowledge exchange loop, ensuring that theoretical predictions are continuously refined and validated through empirical studies.

Computer simulations will play a critical role in revealing complex reaction networks, directing selectivity, and preventing catalyst deactivation. The project will lead to the creation of multifunctional catalyst systems that are specifically engineered to drive desired reactions while resisting decay. The expected outcomes include the development of new theoretical concepts, methodological advances in catalyst design, and the synthesis of superior catalyst systems suitable for liquid phase chemical transformations.

DeLiCAT's impact will be felt across multiple fields of application, including biomass valorization, catalysis, and hydrogen technology, making it a significant contributor to sustainable industrial processes. This unified, first-principles-guided approach promises to set a new standard for catalyst development, with the potential to deliver both environmental and economic benefits.
